items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Summary Report of Student Achievement 2007-2008 and Program Improvement DESCRIPTION: The California STAR accountability program is in the tenth year of administration. East Side Union High School District students in grades 9-11 took the State mandated California Standards Tests (CST) and the California High School Exit Exam.  Together these assessments make up the elements of the Accountability Reporting System:  Academic Performance Index (API), Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP), and Program Improvement (PI).Students in grades 9-11 took tests in reading, mathematics, English language arts, science, and social science. Students in grades 10 took the CAHSEE for the first time. Students who did not pass the CAHSEE previously also had additional testing opportunities. The following is a list of highlights:California Standards TestsGrades 9 and 10 demonstrated significant increases in proficiency compared to two years ago in English Language Arts.There was an increase in the number of 9th grade students taking Geometry and a decrease in the number of students taking Algebra 1ESUHSD showed increases in the percent proficient for all core science courses.A significant achievement gap still persists between Asian and African American and Hispanic students, as well as a gap due to language proficiency, socio economics, and disability. California High School Exit ExamESUHSD showed a 4% gain over the last four years in both English Language Arts and Mathematics in the % of students passing the CAHSEE on their first attempt. All subgroups except EL and SPED met their AMO targets for percent proficient. 	The district is in Program Improvement Year-3 as a result of not meeting AYP in the areas of:  graduation rate, and proficiency levels.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the above report.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, Superintendent and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal CounselSUBJECT:ESUHSD Education Foundation Update; Appoint Board Member to Serve as Representative to FoundationThe Foundation was created as a legal entity on August 27, 2008, with the filing of the Articles of Incorporation with the California Secretary of State.  The Articles of Incorporation were signed by Superintendent Nunez as the “sole incorporator” of the Foundation.  As a result, the Foundation can now actively solicit funds and donations and Legal Counsel is providing guidance as to the necessary and appropriate disclosures to be made for fundraising purposes.To perfect the formation of the Foundation, Officers and Directors of the Foundation must now be appointed who will then adopt By-Laws (including among other things the size and make-up of the Board of Directors, length of terms, etc.) and nominate and appoint a full Board of Directors to serve on the Foundation board.  To accomplish this, Legal Counsel recommends that an initial Board of Directors of three persons be selected and further recommends that the Governing Board appoint one of its members to sit on the initial board of the Foundation, with the remaining person to be selected by the Superintendent.The initial Board will then meet within the next 10-14 days and hold its first meeting to discuss the adoption of appropriate By-Laws for the organization.  Once the By-Laws are approved, the final application for tax-exempt status can be completed and submitted to the IRS.  A six to ten month approval process is contemplated.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneRECOMMENDATION:Select a member of the Governing Board to serve as liaison and as initial member of Board of Directors of the Foundation.

Perkins Vocational Education Act of 1998, under Section 131 – Secondary Education, has recommended East Side Union High School District for funding for 2008-2012.  The Perkins Act directs us to: (1) continuously upgrade and improve vocational career-technical education programs, (2) integrate academies with vocational education through a coherent sequence of courses to ensure learning in the core academic and technical subjects, (3) provide students with strong experience and understanding of all aspects of an industry, (4) develop, improve, or expand the use of technology in career technical education, (5) provide professional development to vocational teachers, administrators, and counselors, and (6) develop and implement evaluations of vocational and technical education programs carried out with Perkins funds, including assessment of how the needs of special populations are being met.Accomplishments:Our CTE Advisory Committee has reviewed and recommended the development of integrated career programs in the form of academy and CTE cluster programs, identification and training of teacher teams, and continued to monitor the integration of instruction through incorporation of core subject standards and relevancy activities. These include increasing access for special population students, implementing activities to ensure that students are developing employability skills, and increasing work-based learning opportunities for studentsThis Local Plan for 2008 – 2012 replaces the ESUHSD Career and Technical Education Plan.  It was developed to meet the requirements of the Perkins Act.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. FortĂŠ, Director of Career ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Plan for Implementation of Course Sequencing as Required by AB 2448Overview:Assembly Bill 2448 was passed in January of 2007 to help Regional Occupational Center Programs (ROCPs), community colleges, and high schools work together to create meaningful pathways for students.  ABB 2448 requires that the governing board of each ROCP shall ensure that at least 90% of all state-funded courses offered by the ROCP in occupational areas in which both the ROCP and the community college offer instruction are part of occupational course sequences that target comprehensive skills.  AB 2448 also requires that the Governing Board of each ROCP develop a plan for establishing sequences of courses on or before July 1, 2008.  The approved plan must be submitted to the appropriate community colleges in the region and the State Superintendent of Public Instruction (SPI) on or before September 1, 2008.In addition, AB 2448 requires that the approved plan be presented at a public hearing by the governing board of each district served by the ROCP and by the County Board of Education.  Community college districts served by the ROCP must review the plans in a public session.  The purpose of this Board Memo is to set the stage for the ESUHSD governing board to approve MetroEd’s Plan for Implementing ROCP Course Sequencing (attached).Accomplishments:The MetroEd plan for establishing course sequences for its ROCP classes is attached to this Board memo.  The plan has been submitted to the Superintendent of Public Instruction and participating community colleges.  The six participating districts are now required to schedule the public hearings.  ESUHSD is one of the six participating districts.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Plan for Implementation of Course Sequencing as Required by AB 2448.
